bugs.title: CVE-2022-32189 golang: math/big: decoding big.Float and big.Rat types can panic if the encoded message is too short, potentially allowing a denial of service

bugzilla.short_desc: CVE-2022-32189 golang: math/big: decoding big.Float and big.Rat types can panic if the encoded message is too short, potentially allowing a denial of service

long_desc.thetext:
A too-short encoded message can cause a panic in Float.GobDecode and Rat.GobDecode in math/big in Go before 1.17.13 and 1.18.5, potentially allowing a denial of service.

References:
https://go.dev/issue/53871
https://groups.google.com/g/golang-nuts/c/DCFSyTGM0wU

Upstream Commits:
Master : https://github.com/golang/go/commit/055113ef364337607e3e72ed7d48df67fde6fc66
Branch.go1.17 : https://github.com/golang/go/commit/703c8ab7e5ba75c95553d4e249309297abad7102
Branch.go1.18 : https://github.com/golang/go/commit/9240558e4f342fc6e98fec22de17c04b45089349

bugs.title: CVE-2022-32190 golang: net/url: JoinPath does not strip relative path components in all circumstances

bugzilla.short_desc: CVE-2022-32190 golang: net/url: JoinPath does not strip relative path components in all circumstances

long_desc.thetext:
JoinPath and URL.JoinPath would not remove ../ path components appended to a relative path. For example, JoinPath("https://go.dev", "../go") returned the URL https://go.dev/../go, despite the JoinPath documentation stating that ../ path elements are cleaned from the result.

References:
https://go.dev/issue/54385
https://groups.google.com/g/golang-announce/c/x49AQzIVX-s/m/0tgO0pjiBQAJ

Upstream Commits:
Master : https://github.com/golang/go/commit/0765da5884adcc8b744979303a36a27092d8fc51
Branch.go1.19 : https://github.com/golang/go/commit/28335508913a46e05ef0c04a18e8a1a6beb775ec

bugs.title: CVE-2022-27664 golang: net/http: handle server errors after sending GOAWAY

bugzilla.short_desc: CVE-2022-27664 golang: net/http: handle server errors after sending GOAWAY

long_desc.thetext:
A closing HTTP/2 server connection could hang forever waiting for a clean shutdown that was preempted by a subsequent fatal error. This failure mode could be exploited to cause a denial of service.

References:
https://go.dev/issue/54658
https://groups.google.com/g/golang-announce/c/x49AQzIVX-s/m/0tgO0pjiBQAJ

bugs.title: CVE-2022-32190 golang: net/url: JoinPath does not strip relative path components in all circumstances [epel-all]

bugzilla.short_desc: CVE-2022-32190 golang: net/url: JoinPath does not strip relative path components in all circumstances [epel-all]

blocked.short_desc: CVE-2022-32190 golang: net/url: JoinPath does not strip relative path components in all circumstances

long_desc.thetext:
JoinPath and URL.JoinPath would not remove ../ path components appended to a relative path. For example, JoinPath("https://go.dev", "../go") returned the URL https://go.dev/../go, despite the JoinPath documentation stating that ../ path elements are cleaned from the result.

References:
https://go.dev/issue/54385
https://groups.google.com/g/golang-announce/c/x49AQzIVX-s/m/0tgO0pjiBQAJ

bugs.title: CVE-2022-2879 golang: archive/tar: unbounded memory consumption when reading headers

bugzilla.short_desc: CVE-2022-2879 golang: archive/tar: unbounded memory consumption when reading headers

long_desc.thetext:
Reader.Read did not set a limit on the maximum size of file headers. A maliciously crafted archive could cause Read to allocate unbounded amounts of memory, potentially causing resource exhaustion or panics. Reader.Read now limits the maximum size of header blocks to 1 MiB.

Ref: https://groups.google.com/g/golang-announce/c/xtuG5faxtaU?pli=1

bugs.title: CVE-2022-2880 golang: net/http/httputil: ReverseProxy should not forward unparseable query parameters

bugzilla.short_desc: CVE-2022-2880 golang: net/http/httputil: ReverseProxy should not forward unparseable query parameters

long_desc.thetext:
Requests forwarded by ReverseProxy included the raw query parameters from the inbound request, including unparseable parameters rejected by net/http. This could permit query parameter smuggling when a Go proxy forwards a parameter with an unparseable value.

ReverseProxy will now sanitize the query parameters in the forwarded query when the outbound request's Form field is set after the ReverseProxy.Director function returns, indicating that the proxy has parsed the query parameters. Proxies which do not parse query parameters continue to forward the original query parameters unchanged.

Ref: https://groups.google.com/g/golang-announce/c/xtuG5faxtaU?pli=1

bugs.title: CVE-2022-41715 golang: regexp/syntax: limit memory used by parsing regexps

bugzilla.short_desc: CVE-2022-41715 golang: regexp/syntax: limit memory used by parsing regexps

long_desc.thetext:
The parsed regexp representation is linear in the size of the input, but in some cases the constant factor can be as high as 40,000, making relatively small regexps consume much larger amounts of memory.

Each regexp being parsed is now limited to a 256 MB memory footprint. Regular expressions whose representation would use more space than that are now rejected. Normal use of regular expressions is unaffected.

ref: https://groups.google.com/g/golang-announce/c/xtuG5faxtaU?pli=1

bugs.title: CVE-2022-2880 golang: net/http/httputil: ReverseProxy should not forward unparseable query parameters [epel-all]

bugzilla.short_desc: CVE-2022-2880 golang: net/http/httputil: ReverseProxy should not forward unparseable query parameters [epel-all]

blocked.short_desc: CVE-2022-2880 golang: net/http/httputil: ReverseProxy should not forward unparseable query parameters

long_desc.thetext:
Requests forwarded by ReverseProxy included the raw query parameters from the inbound request, including unparseable parameters rejected by net/http. This could permit query parameter smuggling when a Go proxy forwards a parameter with an unparseable value.

ReverseProxy will now sanitize the query parameters in the forwarded query when the outbound request's Form field is set after the ReverseProxy.Director function returns, indicating that the proxy has parsed the query parameters. Proxies which do not parse query parameters continue to forward the original query parameters unchanged.

Ref: https://groups.google.com/g/golang-announce/c/xtuG5faxtaU?pli=1

bugs.title: CVE-2022-2879 golang: archive/tar: unbounded memory consumption when reading headers [epel-all]

bugzilla.short_desc: CVE-2022-2879 golang: archive/tar: unbounded memory consumption when reading headers [epel-all]

blocked.short_desc: CVE-2022-2879 golang: archive/tar: unbounded memory consumption when reading headers

long_desc.thetext:
Reader.Read did not set a limit on the maximum size of file headers. A maliciously crafted archive could cause Read to allocate unbounded amounts of memory, potentially causing resource exhaustion or panics. Reader.Read now limits the maximum size of header blocks to 1 MiB.

Ref: https://groups.google.com/g/golang-announce/c/xtuG5faxtaU?pli=1

bugs.title: CVE-2022-41720 golang: os, net/http: avoid escapes from os.DirFS and http.Dir on Windows

bugzilla.short_desc: CVE-2022-41720 golang: os, net/http: avoid escapes from os.DirFS and http.Dir on Windows

long_desc.thetext:
On Windows, restricted files can be accessed via os.DirFS and http.Dir. The os.DirFS function and http.Dir type provide access to a tree of files rooted at a given directory. These functions permit access to Windows device files under that root. For example, os.DirFS("C:/tmp").Open("COM1") opens the COM1 device. Both os.DirFS and http.Dir only provide read-only filesystem access. In addition, on Windows, an os.DirFS for the directory (the root of the current drive) can permit a maliciously crafted path to escape from the drive and access any path on the system. With fix applied, the behavior of os.DirFS("") has changed. Previously, an empty root was treated equivalently to "/", so os.DirFS("").Open("tmp") would open the path "/tmp". This now returns an error.

https://groups.google.com/g/golang-announce/c/L_3rmdT0BMU/m/yZDrXjIiBQAJ
https://pkg.go.dev/vuln/GO-2022-1143

bugs.title: CVE-2022-41717 golang: net/http: excessive memory growth in a Go server accepting HTTP/2 requests

bugzilla.short_desc: CVE-2022-41717 golang: net/http: excessive memory growth in a Go server accepting HTTP/2 requests

long_desc.thetext:
An attacker can cause excessive memory growth in a Go server accepting HTTP/2 requests. HTTP/2 server connections contain a cache of HTTP header keys sent by the client. While the total number of entries in this cache is capped, an attacker sending very large keys can cause the server to allocate approximately 64 MiB per open connection.

bugs.title: CVE-2022-41720 golang: os, net/http: avoid escapes from os.DirFS and http.Dir on Windows [epel-all]

bugzilla.short_desc: CVE-2022-41720 golang: os, net/http: avoid escapes from os.DirFS and http.Dir on Windows [epel-all]

blocked.short_desc: CVE-2022-41720 golang: os, net/http: avoid escapes from os.DirFS and http.Dir on Windows

long_desc.thetext:
On Windows, restricted files can be accessed via os.DirFS and http.Dir. The os.DirFS function and http.Dir type provide access to a tree of files rooted at a given directory. These functions permit access to Windows device files under that root. For example, os.DirFS("C:/tmp").Open("COM1") opens the COM1 device. Both os.DirFS and http.Dir only provide read-only filesystem access. In addition, on Windows, an os.DirFS for the directory (the root of the current drive) can permit a maliciously crafted path to escape from the drive and access any path on the system. With fix applied, the behavior of os.DirFS("") has changed. Previously, an empty root was treated equivalently to "/", so os.DirFS("").Open("tmp") would open the path "/tmp". This now returns an error.

https://groups.google.com/g/golang-announce/c/L_3rmdT0BMU/m/yZDrXjIiBQAJ
https://pkg.go.dev/vuln/GO-2022-1143
https://go.dev/cl/455716
https://go.dev/issue/56694

bugs.title: CVE-2022-41717 golang: net/http: An attacker can cause excessive memory growth in a Go server accepting HTTP/2 requests [epel-all]

bugzilla.short_desc: CVE-2022-41717 golang: net/http: An attacker can cause excessive memory growth in a Go server accepting HTTP/2 requests [epel-all]

blocked.short_desc: CVE-2022-41717 golang: net/http: excessive memory growth in a Go server accepting HTTP/2 requests

long_desc.thetext:
An attacker can cause excessive memory growth in a Go server accepting HTTP/2 requests. HTTP/2 server connections contain a cache of HTTP header keys sent by the client. While the total number of entries in this cache is capped, an attacker sending very large keys can cause the server to allocate approximately 64 MiB per open connection.

blocked.short_desc: CVE-2022-41717 caddy: golang: net/http: An attacker can cause excessive memory growth in a Go server accepting HTTP/2 requests [epel-7]
CVE-2022-41717 golang: net/http: excessive memory growth in a Go server accepting HTTP/2 requests

long_desc.thetext:
An attacker can cause excessive memory growth in a Go server accepting HTTP/2 requests. HTTP/2 server connections contain a cache of HTTP header keys sent by the client. While the total number of entries in this cache is capped, an attacker sending very large keys can cause the server to allocate approximately 64 MiB per open connection.

https://groups.google.com/g/golang-announce/c/L_3rmdT0BMU/m/yZDrXjIiBQAJ
https://pkg.go.dev/vuln/GO-2022-1144
https://go.dev/cl/455717
https://go.dev/issue/56350
https://go.dev/cl/455635

For posterity, this update ended up being broken and nobody (myself included) caught it while it was in the testing repo.  It's no longer possible to build caddy v1 with the golang that is in EPEL 7.  The choice was between an incompatible update to caddy v2 (major breaking changes with a new config file format) or retiring the package.  With only 10 months left until EPEL 7 is retired, I decided to go with the latter.  See this email for more details.
